summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Laura Menninger and Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding discovery issues in the U.S. v. Maxwell case. The emails discuss logistical arrangements for reviewing evidence (hard drives, boots, photos), discrepancies in the count of 'Highly Confidential' images, problems with document accessibility, and the process for de-designating materials. The exchanges highlight defense challenges in accessing and reviewing voluminous evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Lead defense counsel corresponding with prosecutors about discovery issues, including reviewing hard drives, boots, and photos seized from Epstein's properties, and challenging the handling of 'Highly Confidential' materials.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the U.S. v. Maxwell case.

persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the U.S. v. Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in U.S. v. Maxwell; her defense team is seeking to review evidence with her and address problems with document accessibility at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Evidence discussed in the correspondence was seized from his New York residence and devices; the materials include thousands of images and videos extracted from CDs and hard drives.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to her order (Dkt. No. 322) that the parties are meeting and conferring about.

events.title: Scheduled trial date for U.S. v. Maxwell

events.title: Defense evidence review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel traveled to New York to review evidence, including hard drives containing 'Highly Confidential' materials, but encountered technical problems with readers and disks.

events.title: FBI Report on HC materials count
events.description: FBI report indicated approximately 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos from CART-processed evidence, revealing a discrepancy with earlier verbal estimates given to defense.

MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell is held)
keyFacts: Prosecutors disclosed a massive volume of 'Highly Confidential' images and videos: approximately 40,000 images from CDs seized from Epstein's NY residence, plus approximately 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos from Epstein's devices according to an FBI report.
A significant discrepancy existed in the count of HC materials: defense was initially told ~2,100 nude images from Epstein's devices, but an FBI report indicated ~34,000 HC images/videos.
The defense faced major technical hurdles reviewing discovery: corrupt files, missing metadata, unreadable file formats, and inability to match photos with metadata, hindering trial preparation.
The FBI was conducting a de-designation review to reclassify images that do not depict genitals, breasts, or buttocks from 'Highly Confidential' to 'Confidential' for production to the defense.
Physical evidence included boots recently taken into evidence and original VRG photos that could only be reviewed in person in New York under FBI supervision.
